instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1286: What is A1286? A1286 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2009 , Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2255, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2330, 820-2532, 820-2523, 820-2533, 820-2850, 820-2915, 820-3330..
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15‚Äù Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans on high, no ASD error
threads.message:
Hi, 
I've got a 2012 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> here. Fans going full speed and clock speed is low, but EFI ASD doesn't find any errors. 

Known history:
1) BIOS was corrupted --> reflashed
2) Accidentally bridged <CAPACITOR>C8900</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C8901</CAPACITOR> during reflow of <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> putting 12V (<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0_GFXIMVP</SIGNAL>) on the 5V rail (<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_GFXIMVP_VDD</SIGNAL>). Big whoops.
2a) Replaced <CHIP>U8900</CHIP>
2b) Replaced <CHIP>U7300</CHIP>

For now anything that uses 5V is suspect to me. Any way to narrow this down?

Thanks!

Rick

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans on high, no ASD error
threads.message: Where did the BIOS come from? Was the fan issue already there or only after the fuck up?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans on high, no ASD error
threads.message: Because the original BIOS was beyond repair, I replaced it with one from the Ghostlyhaks repository (with new ME, cleaned $SVS and replaced serial). I know some of these are faulty, but I don't have any alternatives at the moment. Come to think of it, the fan issue appeared after the BIOS flash. Any ideas where to get a proper BIOS for this model?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans on high, no ASD error
threads.message: Find a dump from anywhere for testing and it should not cause the fan to run high. Do the fans rev up immediately or does it take a while?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans on high, no ASD error
threads.message: Thanks Duke, will do. Fans rev up after a few seconds. I think I have another one of these board so I'll try dumping that tomorrow.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans on high, no ASD error
threads.message: Nope, no improvement with another dump. I must be something related to the 12V being put on the 5V rail, that ASD is not picking up on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans on high, no ASD error
threads.message: Disconnect the camera cable, that is the only thing fed by 5V that contains a temp sensor.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans on high, no ASD error
threads.message:
No improvement. Also, the ambient light sensor is working fine. What temperature sensor are you talking about Duke? 
All temperature sensor readings look fine in ASD. The following sensor reading are off, but don't give an ASD-error:
IC0C = 0 (should be between 1 and 44)
ID0R = 0.037 (should be between 0.1 and 4.4)
IG0C = 0 (should be between 1 and 20)
PCPC/G/T = -254
VD0R = 15,8 (should be between 11,27 and 12,6)

I think the last one is <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> which measures 12,57 on the DMM. Maybe <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans on high, no ASD error
threads.message: Replaced <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>, fans still running on high speed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans on high, no ASD error
threads.message: The fans are running on 5V. Have you done the obvious and try another fan? ASD must give an error when testing the fans too!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans on high, no ASD error
threads.message:
As you said, this would have shown up in ASD. When testing, ASD lowers the fan speed, suggesting the fans and fan controllers are fine. Also, the clock speed is lowered, indicating a sensor issue I suppose.

I still kind of suspect the EFI. Some help would be appreciated.
* I've dumped a working ROM from an identical model (EMC2556)
* Replaced the ME-region with 'clean' one (identical version) from dodgy Vietnamse site
* Replaced the serial
* Flashed it, now it won't start

Two questions:
1) Is it OK to use a higher version ME-region? (mine is 8.0.4.1441, but only v8.1.70.1590 is available on the winraid forum)
2) Is removing the first $SVS block necessary when there's no lock on the machine the dump was pulled from?

Thanks again people :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans on high, no ASD error
threads.message:
The EFI will not cause the fan to run high. You can just use the dump as-is and the fan should run normal. The ME region may just prevent it from fully booting.

I really have no other ideas at the moment.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Fans on high, no ASD error
threads.message: Got tired of this one, made it a donor board :) Thanks Duke!
